The North Pole

The North Pole was one of the last remaining laurels of earthly exploration, a prize for which countless explorers from many nations had suffered and died for 300 years. And here was the american explorer Robert E. Peary sending word from Indian Harbour, Labrador, that he had reached the pole in April 1909.

At the beggining

In 1519, a large squadron sailed from Spain, aiming to find a western sea route to Asia. At the head is the Portuguese Fernando Magellan. His five ships sailed farther south along with South America, discovering La Plata Bay, which was originally considered a strait. With many vicissitudes (even a revolt) in 1520, Magellan crossed a narrow and dangerous strait, named today after him

The ice crush

The ice crushed Long's ship, he and half his crew perished, which posed a major problem for future researchers. The Norwegian Fritjof Nansen created the ship Fram, which can survive in these conditions. Thus, in 1895, he passed with one satellite beyond the 86th parallel (450 km from the pole).

The real discoverer

In September 7, 1909, readers of the New York Times awakened to a stunning front-page headline: "Peary Discovers the North Pole After Eight Trials in 23 Years." The Times story alone would have been astounding. But it wasn't alone. A week earlier, the New York Herald had printed its own front-page headline: "The North Pole is Discovered by Dr. Frederick A. Cook." Cook, an American explorer who had seemingly returned from the dead after more than a year in the Arctic, claimed to have reached the pole in April 1908—a full year before Peary.
